prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We target mainly the continuum. So, we use the TDMs in all spectral windows. We ask for continuum imaging in band 6 with the maximal bandwidth (8 GHz) with the highest possible central frequency.

The overheahds caused by numerous pointings limits the efficiency of these shallow surveys. We thus reduce the spacing to 0.8. This divides the number of pointings by a factor of 2.4, reducing significantly the overheads. The heterogeneity of the coverage is only 5% (variation of 10% of the noise). This can be easily taken into account in our statistical interpretation of the survey.

The dust emission increases with the frequency. However, higher frequencies implies higher noise and smaller beam (and thus slower mapping speed). Our simulations showed that the highest frequencies of band 6 are optimal to maximize the number of detections per hour.

The typical size of the galaxy we target is 0.5-1 arcsec. We do not want to resolve these sources to maximize the sensitivity to the integrated flux density (no flux spreading in several beams). However, we need also a good resolution to find the counterparts of our sources. We thus chose a resolution of 1 arcsec.
Our survey is splitted in 6 indentical sub-mosaics to stay below the limit of 150 pointings. These mosaics are offset to follow a regular patterm after being combined.

Band choice: We compared the number of detections in bands 3, 6 and 7. Low frequencies provide larger field sizes, but the dust emission of galaxies is much weaker. We find that band 6 provides the highest number of detections for the same amount of time (see also Da Cunha et al. 2013, ApJ765, 9). To fine tune the central frequency of the survey, we compared the number of detections at 265 GHz (1.1mm) and 220 GHz (1.3mm) and finally settled for a band 6 around 265 Ghz. Note that our choice of 1.1mm allows to detect 1.4-1.7 less luminous galaxies than the 1.3mm band used in the Cycle 1 HUDF 4sq.arcmin ultra-deep survey (PI Dunlop) for sources at z=2 to 6 respectively. We find that for typical IR SEDs, the 0.03mJy-rms depth in the 4sq.arcmin HUDF survey at 1.3mm converts into an equivalent depth of 0.05mJy-rms at 1.1mm, hence only 2.5 times deeper.
Requested sensitivity: We request a 0.128 mJy RMS sensitivity.
Line detection: The 384microJy/beam 3-sigma continuum sensitivity corresponds to a 3-sigma line sensitivity of ~1.6 mJy/beam or (assuming a typical line width of 300 km/s) 0.5 Jy km/s for the integrated line flux. At this flux limit, one expects to detect about 0.2 source/sq.arcmin in CO line-emission (equivalently distributed in 3-2, 4-3, 5-4 CO transitions at different redshifts, model of Sargent+13), hence a total of 14 sources for the whole field. Stacking on samples of sources will allow the detection of average CO emission for a much larger galaxy population. Given the 8 GHz instantaneous bandwidth of ALMA centered on 265 GHz, [CII] is accessible for galaxies around z~6 within Delta(z)~0.2.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to carry out a wide (10'x6.8') and deep (128 microJy rms) ALMA 1.1mm survey in GOODS-South requiring 21.9 hrs of observing time. The combined power of ALMA and Herschel will probe the dust (hence also gas) content and SFR (hence SFE=SFR/Mgas) of galaxies out to z=3.5. It will also open a new window on previously undiscovered dusty star formation out to z~6-8, an era previously studied only with UV emission and untested extinction corrections. With ALMA's exquisite angular resolution and sensitivity, >4-10 times deeper than existing sub-mm surveys, these data will provide the missing link between the obscured and unobscured Universe, allowing the deconfusion of Herschel data and permitting statistical studies of galaxy populations via detections and stacking. Our team brings together astronomers with extensive experience with the GOODS-S multi-wavelength dataset, especially Herschel, JVLA, HST and Chandra. In comparison to the previous Cycle 1 ALMA 1.3mm survey in the HUDF, we will cover a 17x wider area, detect 5-7 times more sources, and reach a complete census on the cosmic SFR density of M*>3-4x10^10 Msun galaxies over z=0-6 with ~0.15 dex uncertainty.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
